entry.title: Re: Can SAC work like power pivot from Excel?
entry.content:
@quincycheng1992 SAC and Power pivot /BI behaves a bit different. The data model in power pivot lets you create the join between the tables while defining the data model and also define the filter direction. SAC just allows for blending and filtering of data using the common linked dimension. What you could try is adding the linked dimension to the filter section of the chart if its being forced for rendering.

 

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA Studio: Error while exporting tables and calculation views
entry.content:
If you want to export to other instances, you need to export this table using sql like: EXPORT EXPORT_TABLE_XXX ...'  (This is not to export to another table, this is to export this table to a directory). 
And if this table is larger than 2GB, then it cannot be exported to local client.
It has to be exported to Cloud storages or via Data Lake. Then import to another instance.

But if you really need it locally than you have only one option left to break the table into pieces and move data in batches. you can acheive that by creating a table using "like" then moving some data, than export that than truncate the table than insert and export next batch and so on...

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori ‚Äì Organizing your My Home page
entry.content:
Hi MKGandhi

Yes! The My Home Settings > Advanced > Export/Import would be perfect to save your settings (export) before the refresh and  import them again afterwards.

However I would also counsel the users to reconsider adding 100 tiles in favorite apps !  For custom business roles or where there was a special process we created a custom space/page for the role - that‚Äôs a development object you can capture to a transport request to export and reapply after refresh.  

At the very least group up your apps! 

And remember if your access permissions change any apps you are NOT authorised to see will be automatically hidden.  If you suspect that has happened you can go to any SAP Fiori app in the same user session and use the User Actions > App Support feature to check the SAPUI5 Log Messages section for hidden tile visualisations.

entry.title: Re: BAPI_CHARACT_CREATE shows success, but the characteri...
entry.content:
Update: This question has been resolved and is now marked as closed.

I found a way to make it work by running the BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT using Test Sequences in SE37, the characteristic gets saved properly and becomes visible in CT04.

So, if you're facing the same issue:

Use Test Sequences to call BAPI_CHARACT_CREATE, followed by BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT

This ensures that the transaction is finalised, and the characteristic is immediately active without ECM-related issues.

Thanks to everyone who viewed the post!

entry.title: FM BCS Total Release hierarchy check
entry.content:
Hello,

My client is migrating from the Former Budget to Budget Control System.
Release scenario is being used.
Commitment items is mange in the standard hierarchy where all "son" commitment items have "father" commitment item.
Today, at Former Budget Profile there is an availability control that checks that the total release budget at ‚Äúson" commitment items equal or lower than the release budget at "father" commitment item. Standard error BQ111 display when this condition is not met.

What is the preferred / standard way to reproduce this availability control at FM BCS ?

I try to check the following direction:

  1. BCS AVC Budget to Budget Ledger ‚Äì I didn't find a way to distinguish "fathers" release budget from "sons" release budget as there is no way to filter release budget type at AVC ledger consumable budget.
  2. Consistency check - requires developing Z key figures that sums "sons" total release budget.
  3. Badi FMKU_BUDGET_EVENT - develop the required check from scratch.

Thanks,
Amit Blumshtein

entry.title: How are SAP Cloud Portal Service, Administrator users counted
entry.content:
Hi,

I have the following query from a customer interaction. Client has SAP BTP Neo environment with the SAP Cloud Portal Service. They have multiple sub-accounts (80+) where this service is deployed, but only a few Cloud Portal administrators are configured to manage the entire landscape. 

So though there are around 15 Portal Administrator working across multiple BTP sub-accounts, the monthly count is aggregated multiple times for the same unique user.  So the total Portal Administrator count is around 80+ though there are only 15 unique Portal Administrators.

I would like to understand whether the Portal Administrators are aggregated on a sub-account level, and if the same user works across multiple sub-accounts then they are counted multiple times. 

Thanks,

entry.title: Event driven architecture Postman to Solace: Event Publishing Using SAP CPI : part-4
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

In this blog i would like to share the implementation of publisher part of my use case Event driven architecture using solace Event broker.

Step-1 : Setup a postman :

Use the method POST and use the SAP cpi endpoint in the url section  and hit with the target payload that i am given below

Payload:

If its product's:

<Products>
    <Product>
        <ProductID>P1001</ProductID>
        <ProductName>Wireless Mouse</ProductName>
        <Category>Electronics</Category>
        <Price>25.99</Price>
        <Currency>USD</Currency>
        <StockQuantity>150</StockQuantity>
        <UnitOfMeasure>EA</UnitOfMeasure>
        <Supplier>LogiTech Inc.</Supplier>
    </Product>
 </Products>

If it's suppliers :

<Suppliers>
    <Supplier>
        <ID>P1001</ID>
        <Name>Wireless Mouse</Name>
        <Category>Electronics</Category>
        <Price>27.99</Price>
        <Currency>USD</Currency>
        <StockQuantity>200</StockQuantity>
        <UnitOfMeasure>EA</UnitOfMeasure>
        <Supplier>LogiTech Inc.</Supplier>
    </Supplier>
</Suppliers>

Step-2: Implementing layer-1-Routing layer:

1.start with HTTPS sender adapter

2.Add the Groovy Script to separate the target 2nd layer

Here is the groovy code :

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.util.XmlSlurper

Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String) // Get XML as a string
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body) // Parse XML

    def targetRoute = ""

    // Check the root element or a specific tag (adjust as needed)
    if (xml.name() == "Products") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_products_layer-2"
    } else if (xml.name() == "Suppliers") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_suppliers_layer_2"
    } else {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_books_layer_2"
    }

    message.setProperty("routeTo", targetRoute) // Store the route in a property
    return message
}

Implementation: This is the Routing layer paste the groovy code that i given above .

Implement the Exception Handling like the below

Declare the content modifier like below add Exchange properties like below

Add the routing condition to separate whether it is recoverable/non-recoverable errors

Based the routing condition above implement the Local Integration Process separately this is the Local Integration Process for the retry purpose called by using process call

Implement the content modifier as like the below

Through process direct adapter call the another layers that are global retry layers and jms retry for retry purpose

Based the routing condition above implement the Local Integration Process separately this is the Local Integration Process for the Mail triggering if any Business logic/non-recoverable error occurs called by using process call

Implement the content modifier like the below for mail triggering

Through process direct adapter call the mail triggering iflow

Step-3 : Implementing layer -2: publishing layer :

Here in this layer the data which is coming from the layer 1 is published to the solace queues and in this layer there are multiple layer-2's like products layer2 ,suppliers layer2,books layer2 bases on the first layer the target 2nd layer been hitted.

Implementation:

Configure the Process direct sender adapter that is coming from the layer-1

Configure the Advance Event Mesh adapter to publish the data into the solace queues, before configuring it make sure you had setup the solace credentials in the Security material that i had given in the part-2 of my blog series 

Setup the Exception handling for retry purpose

Implement the Local Integration process for retry purpose  as same as the layer-1 above

Implement the Local Integration process for mail triggering as same like the layer -1 above

 

If you want to know how to implement Error handling using jms please refer my blog .

Link - [ https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/handling-connectivity-and-recoverable-errors-in-sap-cpi-with-jms-queues/ba-p/14137974 ]

I would continue the Subscriber part in the part-5 Stay tuned!!!

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow in India - recap
entry.content:
What an eventful week it was! (No pun intended)..... Together with @ajay_soreng, we did one SAP CodeJam per day - 3 different cities (Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Bengaluru), 5 different locations, 3 different topics (SAP Integration Suite, SAP Build Process Automation, and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh).

Everything was planned to perfection but I had a mental misstep. I mistakenly thought that there was a visa on arrival when traveling to India when in reality it requires applying for an e-visa. Unfortunately, I only found this when I was doing my check-in - Saturday, exactly 12 hours before my flight, a bit late right? I immediately applied for an e-visa but given that it was a Saturday I had to wait till Monday for a resolution. Don't get me wrong, the e-visa process is really good and fast but you can't expect much when you end up applying for it too late.

The adventure only starts here...I joined the first event remotely, from Madrid. Once I receive the e-visa approval, I had 4.5 hours to catch the next plane leaving Madrid heading to India. The second event, I also joined it remotely, but this time from Abu Dhabi. The plane touched ground at 06:35, after going through security, I immediate started searching for a quiet place to join the 2nd CodeJam of the week. Fortunately, I found one :-). Straight after the event, I boarded a plane to Hyderabad - not kidding, I was walking to the gate as we were wrapping up the event. I closed my laptop a minute before boarding. Finally, I made it to Hyderabad Tuesday night and I was able to join the last three events in-person. I sincerely want to apologise to the attendees of the first two events as I wasn't able to be there in-person but it was great meeting you virtually; also, doing the event remotely would have not been possible if it wasn't for the great help and support from @ajay_soreng and @Shilpa_Shankar - Thanks to you both!

Apart from the physical badges (stickers) that many of the attendees got. All attendees of the different SAP CodeJams will get a special SAP Community badge for attending the events ü™™.

 

Mumbai

In Mumbai we did the Connecting systems and services using SAP Integration Suite CodeJam at Colgate office. Thanks Colgate for hosting!

We recently introduced a new exercise where we interact with Slack and send notifications from Cloud Integration to Slack. It was exciting to see many attendees posting their notifications even after the event finished.

Hyderabad

In Hyderabad it was all about SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. We ran the Event-driven integrations CodeJam at two different locations. Thanks Mindset and Infosys for hosting the events. I joined the first one remotely from Abu Dhabi and finally in-person for the second event. 

Bengaluru

Last city part of the SAP Integration Suite CodeJam roadshow. At Bengaluru, we ran the new SAP Build: Event-based processes and also the Connecting systems and services with SAP Integration Suite CodeJams at SAP Labs Bengaluru and Mindset Consulting, thanks for hosting. We were fortunate enough to be joined by the entire SAP Developer Advocates team based in India ( @sheenamk, @eshrinivasan, @Rekha_DR, @Shilpa_Shankar), as well as by @acharyaw - PM for SAP Build Process Automation.

 

Food

Last but certainly not least... all the lovely food that we enjoyed as part of the roadshow. Thanks to all the hosts.... the food was amazing everywhere haha.

Lots of lessons learned from the mental misstep and there might be cool things and opportunities coming up thanks to it. Also, this wouldn't have been possible without @ajay_soreng's help organising the events and supporting me while I was remotely - Thanks!

entry.title: How SAP Cloud ALM Revitalised System Operations?
entry.content:
Blog no #38

Introduction:

In this blog, first I would like to first thank all of you for always showing so much of love and support, and your amazing feedback on my SAP Blogs.

As the ALM is going from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, hence are my blogs.

This blog is all about a story and how an organisation took a journey of digital transformation with help of SAP Cloud ALM.

So it start with a question from one of my previous client in my last organisation.

‚ÄúHow can SAP Cloud ALM help my system‚Äôs operation?‚Äù

This was the exact question a client asked me during a meeting at my previous organization. Simple question‚Äîbut one that hits the very core of IT operations in today‚Äôs SAP landscapes.

I paused.

Should I list down features like a catalog?

Or should I talk about the real value that SAP Cloud ALM brings‚Äîsomething beyond checkboxes and dashboards?

Instead, I replied:

‚ÄúIf used and utilised properly, SAP Cloud ALM can revitalise your system operations.‚Äù

 

That word‚Äîrevitalise‚Äîcaught their attention. And I meant it.

 

 

The Problem: A Ticking Time Bomb

 

 

This customer was constantly firefighting during month-end closures. Long running jobs, job failures were often noticed late, system performance dropped without warning, and integration errors silently piled up in the background.

Most of their issues had symptoms‚Äîbut no visibility.

They had monitoring tools‚Äîbut not actionable insight.

They had alerts‚Äîbut no prioritization.

And their operations team? Overworked and overwhelmed.

The Turning Point: Breathing Life Back Into Operations

 

That‚Äôs when I got the opportunity to show what SAP Cloud ALM could really do when configured with purpose and precision.

Here‚Äôs what we implemented:

 

  • ‚úÖJob & Automation Monitoring: To keep an eye on critical background jobs and get real-time notifications when anything went off-track. Month-end issues? Reduced to a whisper.
  • ‚úÖHealth Monitoring: To detect infrastructure and system degradation before users felt the impact. The system stopped breaking down at peak hours.
  • ‚úÖReal User Monitoring (RUM): Because what‚Äôs more honest than tracking exactly how real users experience the application?
  • ‚úÖPerformance Monitoring: To proactively analyze system performance metrics and trends. No more guessing games.
  • ‚úÖIntegration & Exception Monitoring: To bring visibility into the hidden failures between systems, applications, and interfaces.
  • ‚úÖBusiness Process Monitoring: So the customer could finally look at the big picture‚Äîhow their actual business processes were performing end-to-end.

 

The Result: From Firefighting to Forward-Thinking

Once these capabilities were up and running, the impact was visible:

 

  • üìâFewer escalations.
  • üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Faster root cause identification.
  • üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Peace of mind for operations teams.
  • üìàHigher system reliability and trust across business users.

The customer told me later:

 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like we got our weekends back.‚Äù

 

The Takeaway

SAP Cloud ALM is not just another monitoring tool. If implemented thoughtfully, it becomes the nerve center of your operations.

 

What made the difference here wasn‚Äôt just configuration‚Äîit was intention. Knowing why each monitoring tile matters, and how they tie into your operational goals, is what unlocks real value.

 

So next time someone asks, ‚ÄúHow can SAP Cloud ALM help my operations?‚Äù‚Äîyou could answer like I did.

 

But make sure you show them what it truly means to revitalise.

 

Have you experienced a similar transformation with SAP Cloud ALM? Or are you exploring its potential? Drop your thoughts or questions in the comments‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear your story.

entry.title: Re: Attach Safety Instructions - Substances to Chemical.
entry.content:
Hello

let us start with:https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/1b3596cc5dd5428d887966a4193ddc29/dad1b9efb2e14143a0d63da5cde05e8d.html?locale=en-US

If you read carefully the online help: this would be my story:

You have a "factory" in which you manage chemicals. This can be (or is) in the most cases more than one chemical

Any of these chemicals have different hazards etc.

You need may be to understand first the purpose of a : "Safety Instruction".

First of: the word "factory" is not a good term. Please think of whatever location you can describe there you manage "chemicals".

The variants of such locations are very big. It can be a "big plant/factory" creating only on chemistry, it can be a location there you product many chemicals of different hazards. You can think if a "lab" (e.g. for R&D purpose, or purpose of "analytics" of chemistry) etc.

By "location" need to mange the "safety instruction" different. The challenge is like this:

Example: If you manage X chemicals you can generate X safety instructions

Or you generate a "high level" safey instruction which is not focusing on the "exact" chemical, but "combine" them

Example: warehouse:

You can write done a "white" and "Black" sitution.

a.) the warehouse is used to always store the same chemicals and this will not change by time

b.) or in the warehouse you can have "all"

in most cases it is more a "grey" like situation.

Now you could think like. I always have 10 chemicals (which are always the same). Therefreo you can prepare 10 safety instructions.

In most of the cases; it is different. a "summerized safety instruction" is generated not focusing on a specific chemical

The situation for an "equipment" could be the same.

BUt here you have so many variants how the people define an "equipment".. 

May be read again: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/1b3596cc5dd5428d887966a4193ddc29/8aaef764387541998ca39e664a436536.html?locale=en-US

Here you will see the variant SAP supports.

With best wishes

C.B.

entry.title: How to Get Remaining Balance for Specific Line Item of an Invoice or Advance

Hello Experts,

I‚Äôm trying to get a report in SAP that shows the remaining balance against a particular line item of an invoice or advance payment.

I have already tried the following:

  • J3RFPCR ‚Äì This only shows the original payment document for Special G/L indicator ‚ÄòA‚Äô (Down Payments) but not for other types of transactions.

  • S_ALR_87012105 ‚Äì This doesn‚Äôt provide the line-item level remaining balance information I‚Äôm looking for.

üëâ Internally, the system is working correctly ‚Äì when I run F-53 (Post Outgoing Payment), SAP perfectly shows how much balance is left against that line item and how much I have already adjusted. But I need a report or transaction to view this information directly without going into F-53.

What I need is:

‚úÖ A standard report or method to get the remaining open amount for each line item in an invoice/advance (not just at header level).
‚úÖ Ability to see it for all Special G/L indicators, not just for ‚ÄòA‚Äô.

Is there any:

  • Standard report or transaction code?

  • Table combination or query that can achieve this?

  • Or do I need to go for a custom report? - I have tried table level but didn't get it, BSE_CLR, BSEG

Any suggestions or best practices would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Automatic Profitability Segment Derivation in "Post General Journal Entries" App
entry.content:
Is there any way in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition to automatically derive a profitability segment when posting via the Post General Journal Entries app?

Currently, even when we define custom substitution/validation rules, the system requires us to first manually press "Assign Profitability Segment", and only after that, upon entering the required prerequisite values, the system performs the derivation via the "Derive" button.

Is there any way to bypass this manual process and have the system:

  • automatically derive the profitability segment,

  • without needing to manually assign and trigger derivation?

We are looking for a way to have profitability segments derived seamlessly as part of the journal entry process.

entry.title: Currency Changeover needs on productive SAP S/4 HANA On-Prem and Private Cloud Environment
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog outlines the typical business triggers that drive the need for a currency changeover in a productive SAP S/4HANA environment. It also highlights the possible realization methodology to support such transformations.

General Business Triggers

Currency conversion requirements are usually driven by strategic, regulatory, or compliance-related events that necessitate a change in the currency model of your SAP system. These scenarios often arise during financial transformations, mergers, organizational restructurings, or statutory reporting changes. Common business triggers include:

  • Legal Currency Change in a Country: A country may mandate a change in its local currency due to reasons such as joining a monetary union (e.g., adoption of the Euro), experiencing hyperinflation, or undergoing political or economic reform.
  • Extension of Reporting Currency: The current ERP system may be configured for only one local reporting currency. Due to requirements such as hyperinflation, currency instability, or IFRS reporting, businesses may need to enable an additional parallel local currency in their productive environment.
  • Group Currency Alignment for Global Operations: Companies operating across multiple countries under different subsidiaries may need to establish a unified group reporting currency to align financial reporting across application modules.
  • Change in Corporate Headquarters/ Group Structure/ Merger & Acquisition: A shift in the corporate headquarters or the inclusion of a new entity with a different group currency may require changes to the existing group currency setup for consolidated financial reporting.
  • Parallel Valuation of Inventories in different valuation methods: Organizations may need to enable transfer pricing and support parallel inventory valuations to gain financial insights from different valuation perspectives and meet reporting requirements.

Possible Scenarios of Currency Changeovers in SAP S/4HANA System

Currency changeover requirements in an SAP S/4HANA system can arise in various business scenarios depending on the reporting, legal, or strategic needs. Below are some common scenarios with illustrative examples:

Scenario 1: Change of First Local Currency Across All Company Codes

A requirement to change the primary local currency (currency type 10) consistently in a company code using a fixed exchange rate.

  • Example: Company code 1000 is currently using INR as the first local currency. The requirement is to change it to USD.

Scenario 2: Introduction of a Parallel Currency with Valuation View

Business requires an additional parallel currency integrated across FI and ML, associated with a specific valuation view (e.g., 11, 12, 31, or 32) to support group or profit center valuation.

  • Example: For company code 1000, there is a need to introduce Group Currency in Group Valuation as a parallel valuation view.

Scenario 3: Introduction of a Freely Definable Currency

The need to add a freely definable currency within the FI application module to support additional parallel reporting.

Refer to SAP Note 2334583 ‚Äì Introduction of new currencies / currency types in SAP S/4HANA, which describes how to manage new currencies via the Manage Currencies Cockpit.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce a freely defined currency for additional reporting.

Scenario 4: Changeover of Group Currency (Client Currency)

Changing the Group Currency (currency type 30) across the system consistently‚Äîfor example, from EUR to USD. This may involve replacement across all application modules, such as FI, CO, and ML, where group currency is already in use.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the group currency needs to be changed from USD to EUR.

Scenario 5: Introduction of Group Currency in Systems Without Prior Usage

In systems where Group Currency was not used historically‚Äîsuch as ECC systems using CO currency types 10/20‚Äîthe migration to S/4HANA may result in the CO currency (now known as "Global Currency" - Refer SAP note 2344012 - Currencies in Universal Journal) occupying the KSL field group in the ACDOCA table. Introducing group currency in such a case requires consistent integration across all modules, including FI and CO, and overwriting existing KSL values where necessary.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce Group Currency as both the Controlling Area Currency and an FI-integrated currency (BSEG level).

Scenario 6: Organizational restructure (change Controlling area currency)

Organizational Restructuring such as a merging multiple controlling areas into a single, unified structure to support centralized management may require the alignment of controlling area currencies to ensure consistency across the organizational hierarchy.

Example: There are 3 Controlling Areas 1000, 2000, 3000 with varying currency settings. Requirement is to merge the controlling areas 1000 and 2000 into 3000.

 Scenario 7: Activation of Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA):
To comply with multiple accounting standards, organizations may seek to activate Universal Parallel Accounting, which requires alignment of existing currency configurations and pre-requisites.

Example: For company code 1000, 0L and 1L ledger is active with company code currency (LC1) and group currency (LC2) and a freely defined currency. Requirement is to activate business function UPA and align the currencies and ledger across application module -FI, FI-AA and ML.

Realization Methodology

Once a company code is productive or live with transactional data, changing the configured currency must not be performed by simply transporting the modified configuration. Moving configuration changes without transforming the already posted documents can lead to data inconsistencies in the live system, potentially causing critical disruptions in business processes‚Äîsuch as clearing open invoices.

To make changes in currency settings, both the configuration and the associated transactional data must be transformed. For transforming existing posted documents, the SAP DMLT Currency Conversion Service is required. For more information, refer to the Currency Conversion Solution Brief.

Such data transformations in a live production system demand a highly precise and controlled changeover, ensuring consistency at the database level and seamless continuity of SAP software operations. Therefore, every relevant business scenario should be carefully reviewed in the system, considering current configurations and customizations across all connected application modules.

SAP DMLT offers a technical feasibility study to outline system data dependencies and prerequisite conditions. This is followed by a detailed customer workshop. The realization of the transformation requirement is delivered under a separate professional consulting contract and executed as a project.

The overall delivery process is broadly divided into two parts:

1. Pre-Qualification of Requirement

It is essential to pre-qualify the business requirement to ensure the right-fit transformation solution is offered. This starts with gathering preliminary details about the business requirement and application usage within the system through a technical questionnaire, available at Data Unification & Harmonization.

Based on the responses, SAP can propose a feasibility study to assess the system, evaluate overall complexity, and deliver a detailed proposal. This assessment typically takes around two weeks, including the deployment of analysis tools in the system.

An SAP solution expert will perform the system assessment and present the key insights during a customer workshop session. This is followed by the provision of commercial details through the regional SAP Market Unit.

2. Project Delivery

Depending on the complexity of the engagement, the required number of mock execution cycles will be determined during the scoping phase. In general, data transformation projects of this nature involve a minimum of three mock cycles before the production data cutover. The purpose of a mock execution is to simulate the complete production data conversion, validate the results, and estimate the overall downtime required for the production system. Each mock execution cycle includes several phases, which can be broadly classified as follows:

2.1 Technical Preparation Phase of Add-On (Uptime):

These types of transformation capabilities are deployed into the customer system as a separate add-on, delivered as transportable content. The mock execution system should be a recent copy of the production system, with hardware configuration closely matching that of the production environment. Once the tool content is deployed, the technical preparation phase begins, during which SAP DMLT experts prepare the transformation tool. This phase typically takes 2‚Äì3 weeks and includes uptime activities and the generation of technical programs for the relevant table-fields.

2.2 Data Conversion Phase (Downtime):

After the uptime preparatory activities are completed, the agreed business downtime begins. During this period, currency conversion is performed directly at the database table-field level. All relevant currency values (currency key/amount) are updated in the respective parallel currency fields in affected application areas (e.g., FI-GL, FI-AA, ML, CO etc) using a fixed exchange rate. Such conversions are applied retroactively for all fiscal years and Go-Live is not bound by a key date.

2.3 Post-Conversion Data Reconciliation Phase (Downtime):

Currency conversion may result in rounding differences, especially in accounting areas where specific rules apply‚Äîsuch as clearings that must net to zero. It is generally recommended to ignore rounding differences from previous fiscal years and reconcile only the current fiscal year. For business continuity, reconciliation of current fiscal year data is performed immediately after the conversion to mitigate the impact of rounding differences and to synchronize data across tightly integrated modules such as FI, CO, and ML.

2.4 Post-Processing Testing Phase (Downtime):

Once the reconciliation phase is complete, the transformed system is handed over to the customer‚Äôs IT/application team for a sanity check during downtime. Upon successful completion of the sanity check, the transformed system is reopened for normal business operations.

How to Engage with SAP

If your business requirement involves transforming any currency-related aspect in a live, productive SAP S/4HANA system, you should engage with the SAP Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) consulting team.

There are two primary ways to initiate the engagement:

  1. Create a Support Incident
    Submit an incident via the SAP ONE Support Launchpad under the component:
    CA-LT-SRV (Landscape Transformation Services)
  2. Contact via Email
    Reach out directly to the DMLT Global Consulting Experts by emailing-  sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

The SAP DMLT team will guide you through the pre-assessment process, feasibility evaluation, and project-based service engagement tailored to your specific system and transformation needs.

Reference SAP OSS Notes:

3476589 - Parallel Currency Transformations in S/4HANA

481938 - System Landscape Optimization Services

3229024 - S/4HANA Local Currency Changeover - Central Note

3334743 - S/4HANA / SFIN 720/730: Is a subsequent implementation and activation of a Profit Center Valuation and/or Group valuation possible?

2882025 - Multiple valuation approaches/transfer prices in SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition

175758 - Deactivating transfer prices/multiple valuation approaches

Other References:

Blog Post: DMLT- Currency Conversion Services Overview and Insights

Currencies Managed in Parallel in the Universal Journal | SAP Help Portal

Disclaimer: This blog is intended only for knowledge sharing about currency conversion service on SAP S/4 HANA which might help customer in their landscape transformation requirements. It should not be considered as guideline for performing such transformation services on their own in the SAP landscape. Any data transformation efforts should be thoroughly assessed in consultation with qualified subject matter experts, supported by a comprehensive system study, and aligned with the appropriate approvals from your auditors.

entry.title: Improving Exception Handling using Generative AI in SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI/CPI)
entry.content:
When it comes to integrating different systems within a business, SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI/CPI) capability in Integration Suite Service of SAP BTP is a go-to tool. However, as these integrations become more complex, handling exceptions - errors and issues, efficiently becomes increasingly important. Generative AI can help businesses tackle these challenges by automating error detection and providing useful insights. Here‚Äôs what you can gain from using AI:

  • User - Friendly Error Messages: Sender systems can receive clear, simple error messages that anyone can understand, not just tech experts.
  • Better Monitoring: You can see these user-friendly error message logs in SAP CI/CPI dashboards, making it easier to track and fix issues.
  • Identify Error Causes: AI can help identify why an error occurred, offering a better understanding of the issue.
  • Suggest Solutions: It can also suggest ways to address and fix the error.
  • Simplify Troubleshooting: Both tech and non-tech staff can troubleshoot errors more easily.
  • Reduce Resolution Time: Speed up the process of solving errors.
  • Prepare for the Future: The insights gained can improve how errors are classified and handled in the future by agentic AIs in SAP BTP.

1. Exception Handling

There are two main ways to integrate AI into your error handling processes in SAP CI/CPI:

  1. Exception Subprocess: Incorporate Generative AI into an existing integration flow‚Äôs exception subprocess for smooth operation. Read More
  2. Common Exception Handling iFlow: Set up a separate flow dedicated to handling exceptions, where you pass error information from the main flow for centralized handling. Read More

In this example, I have used  exception subprocess approach within a simple integration flow and Google Gemini AI model.

 

2. Understanding Gen-AI Prompt Format and get API Key

For Google Gemini, go to https://aistudio.google.com/prompts/new_chat and click on Get API Key, Create API Key.

Here, you can see the format of the request which is expected by Google Gemini API.

3. Implementation Steps

Following are the steps which I have implemented in Exception Subprocess

1. Content Modifer - Set APIKey & Gen-AI Prompt
To set the API key and content type as requested by Google Gemini

To set the required prompt format, I have created the below exchange properties and externalized it

Value stored in Gen AI prompt is

{     "contents": [       {         "parts": [           {             "text": " You are an SAP Integration consultant skilled in troubleshooting in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). Above error is persisting while sending the message from sender to receiver system. For this error, Please respond using the following format, with each section clearly separated by a single line break in a direct and professional tone: 1. User-Friendly Error Message: A one sentence error that can be easily understood by non-technical stakeholders 2. Possible Reasons for the Error: List common causes for encountering this error in SAP CPI integration scenarios. 3. Possible Steps to Resolve the Error: Provide possible troubleshooting steps to address the issue and potentially resolve it. 4. HTTP Response: Provide appropriate HTTP error code (numerical value only) to be sent to sender system. "            }         ]       }     ]   }

Note:

All the values are externalized so that, different models like Microsoft Co-pilot or GTP 4 can be used.

2. Groovy script ‚Äì setGenAIPrompt

This script is used to get the error which is caught from the main integration process by the CamelExceptionCaught property, add this error in the prompt to get the tailored response from Gemini and set the prompt structure required by Gemini AI model.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties from the message

    def camelExceptionCaught = message.getProperty("CamelExceptionCaught")

    def genAIPrompt = message.getProperty("GenAIPrompt")

    def startPrompt = message.getProperty("StartPrompt")



    // Initialize updatedGenAIPrompt as null or empty, it'll be used to set message body eventually

    def updatedGenAIPrompt = null

   

    if (genAIPrompt && startPrompt && camelExceptionCaught) {

        // Find the position of startPrompt in genAIPrompt

        def startIndex = genAIPrompt.indexOf(startPrompt)



        if (startIndex != -1) {

            // Insert space and CamelExceptionCaught after StartPrompt

            updatedGenAIPrompt = genAIPrompt.substring(0, startIndex + startPrompt.length()) +

                                 " " +

                                 camelExceptionCaught +

                                 genAIPrompt.substring(startIndex + startPrompt.length())

                                

            // Set the updatedGenAIPrompt back to a message property

            message.setProperty("UpdatedGenAIPrompt", updatedGenAIPrompt)

        }

    }

   

    if (updatedGenAIPrompt != null) {

        // Set the modified prompt as the message body

        message.setBody(updatedGenAIPrompt)

    }

   

    return message

}

3. Request Reply - Call Google Gemini

I have use HTTP adapter to call Google Gemini
URL: https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent

4. Groovy script ‚Äì captureGenAIResponse

This groovy script is used to capture Custom Error, Possible reason and Possible solution for the error from Gen AI response. Also, handle the errors caused if generative AI is not reachable

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message

import groovy.json.JsonSlurper



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties

    def captureCustomErrorKey = message.getProperty("CaptureCustomError")

    def capturePossibleReasonKey = message.getProperty("CapturePossibleReason")

    def capturePossibleSolutionKey = message.getProperty("CapturePossibleSolution")

    def captureHTTPCodeKey = message.getProperty("CaptureHTTPCode")  // This should be "HTTP Response:"



    // Get the message body and parse it as JSON

    def payload = message.getBody(String)

    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper()



    // Initialize extracted values

    def extractedCustomErrorMessage = null

    def extractedPossibleReason = null

    def extractedPossibleSolution = null

    def extractedPHTTPCode = null



    try {

        // Try parsing the JSON

        def parsedJson = jsonSlurper.parseText(payload)

       

        // Extract the text section from the JSON

        def textContent = parsedJson.candidates[0]?.content?.parts[0]?.text



        if (textContent) {

            // Log the text content to verify structure

            messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)?.addAttachmentAsString("Text Content", textContent, "text/plain")



            // Extract values based on keys

            extractedCustomErrorMessage = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, captureCustomErrorKey)

            extractedPossibleReason = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, capturePossibleReasonKey)

            extractedPossibleSolution = extractValueFollowingKey(textContent, capturePossibleSolutionKey)



            // Specifically extract the HTTP response code after "HTTP Response:"

            extractedPHTTPCode = extractHTTPResponseCode(textContent, captureHTTPCodeKey)

        }

    } catch (Exception e) {

        // Log exception and proceed with null outputs

        messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)?.addAttachmentAsString("Exception", e.toString(), "text/plain")

    }



    // Handle extraction results

    message.setProperty("ExtractedCustomErrorMessage", extractedCustomErrorMessage)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPossibleReason", extractedPossibleReason)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPossibleSolution", extractedPossibleSolution)

    message.setProperty("ExtractedPHTTPCode", extractedPHTTPCode)

   

    // Set HTTP Code as the message body for demonstration; it will be null if extraction fails

    message.setBody(extractedPHTTPCode)



    return message

}



// Function to extract value that follows a given key in the text content

def extractValueFollowingKey(String textContent, String key) {

    if (key) {

        def keyIndex = textContent.indexOf(key)

        if (keyIndex != -1) {

            def startIndex = keyIndex + key.length()

            if (startIndex != -1) {

                def endIndex = textContent.indexOf("\n\n", startIndex)

                endIndex = endIndex != -1 ? endIndex : textContent.length()



                def extractedText = textContent.substring(startIndex, endIndex).trim()

                extractedText = extractedText.replaceAll('\\*', '')  // Clean up undesired characters

                return extractedText

            }

        }

    }

    return null

}



// Specific extraction utility for HTTP Code.

def extractHTTPResponseCode(String textContent, String key) {

    if (key) {

        def keyIndex = textContent.indexOf(key)

        if (keyIndex != -1) {

            def startIndex = keyIndex + key.length()

            if (startIndex != -1) {

                // Find the end, which is the next newline after the code and description

                def endIndex = textContent.indexOf("\n", startIndex)

                endIndex = endIndex != -1 ? endIndex : textContent.length()



                return textContent.substring(startIndex, endIndex).trim()

            }

        }

    }

    return null

}

 

5. Content Modifier - Set Content Type for Error Response

In this content modifier the header Content-Type is explicitly set if the error response needs to be sent to the sender system.

6. Groovy Script ‚Äì generateErrorResponse

This script is used to log the custom error in the error log, create custom headers and generate an error response if the sender system needs it. I have implemented all the three in this script to show that it is possible.

Based on your requirement, custom error log or custom header or error response can be set.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message



def Message processData(Message message) {

    // Retrieve properties

    def camelExceptionCaught = message.getProperty("CamelExceptionCaught")

    def extractedCustomErrorMessage = message.getProperty("ExtractedCustomErrorMessage")

    def extractedPossibleReason = message.getProperty("ExtractedPossibleReason")

    def extractedPossibleSolution = message.getProperty("ExtractedPossibleSolution")

    def extractedPHTTPCode = message.getProperty("ExtractedPHTTPCode")



    // Set the CamelHttpResponseCode header

    if (extractedPHTTPCode) {

        message.setHeader("CamelHttpResponseCode", extractedPHTTPCode)

    }



    // Create custom headers

    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message)

    if (messageLog != null) {

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("CustomError", extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: "No custom error message available.")

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("PossibleReason", extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available.")

        messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("PossibleSolution", extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available.")

    }



    // Attach extracted values as message attachments

    def possibleReasonAttachment = extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available."

    def possibleSolutionAttachment = extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available."

   

    if (messageLog != null) {

        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("PossibleReason", possibleReasonAttachment, "text/plain")

        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("PossibleSolution", possibleSolutionAttachment, "text/plain")

    }



    // Create dynamic response in XML format

    def responseXml = """<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<Error_Response>

    <SystemError>${camelExceptionCaught}</SystemError>

    <CustomError>${extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: "No custom error message available."}</CustomError>

    <PossibleReason>${extractedPossibleReason ?: "No possible reason available."}</PossibleReason>

    <PossibleSolution>${extractedPossibleSolution ?: "No possible solution available."}</PossibleSolution>

</Error_Response>"""



    // Set XML response as the message body

    message.setBody(responseXml)





if (camelExceptionCaught) {

        throw new Exception("\nSystem Error: ${camelExceptionCaught}\nCustom Error from GenAI: ${extractedCustomErrorMessage ?: 'No custom error message available.'}")

    }



    return message

}

5. Testing

To test, I am using an API client Bruno, which will mimic the sender system. I have maintained the receiver system URL as http://sample.com. So, the message will fail because it is not a valid URL.

 

1. Triggering the iflow from Bruno as shown below

2.  Without Exception Handling using Gen AI, I get the response as below in Bruno as shown below

3. In the iFlow, I have checked Return Exception to Sender under Error Configuration

4. Now, with Exception Handling using Gen AI, I get the response in Bruno as shown below

5. In Cloud Integration Message Monitoring we see that the message is in error

 

6. Error log is as shown below

7. Custom Headers are successful set with Custom Error, Possible Reason and Possible Solution as shown below

8. Attachments are also set with Possible Reason and Possible Solution as shown below

9. If you have a requirement to send the error response with not just custom error from Gen AI but sending possible reason and solution then set the event in the Exception Subprocess as End Message. The only downside is the message in Cloud Integration will be end with status Completed rather than Error.

Go to Groovy Script - generateErrorResponse and comment the lines 46, 47 and 48 which was done to throw custom exception as shown below

In the script, I am setting the appropriate HTTP code for CamelHttpResponseCode from Google Gemini response.

10. When the message is triggered, we can see that the error response is received in Bruno with correct HTTP response code as shown below.

11. If the correct response code is not set from Google Gemini, then HTTP 200 is received in sender system which will be incorrect, and we can‚Äôt identify if the message failed or not without opening the response message

12. Now, if there is an issue with reaching Generative AI then it is handled in Groovy Scripts. For testing, I will use incorrect URL

6. Conclusion

In this blog, I have tried to provide an overview of how we can make use of Generative AI for Exception Handling in SAP Cloud Integration. Of course, the exception subprocess can be improved and tailored as per the requirement in your integration landscape.

Generative AI offers a new way to handle errors in SAP CI/CPI by automating processes that would typically take much longer. By enhancing error handling, businesses can reduce downtime and improve overall efficiency. With the technology constantly advancing, using AI in exception handling can help businesses stay ahead of the curve, making their operations more reliable. Through simple implementation steps, regular testing, and adapting based on feedback, businesses can fully leverage AI for a smarter, more resilient future.

7. Additional Read

Exception Handling in SAP CPI : SAP Help

I invite you to share your thoughts in the comments below. Whether you have questions about using generative AI for exception handling, experiences to share, or suggestions for improvement, your feedback is invaluable. It helps others who are navigating similar journeys and contributes to a community of shared knowledge. I look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Re: Display keys value in droplist
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma 

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, dropdowns in Fiori apps (like item category) typically show only the description, not the code (key). This behaviour is hardcoded via SAP‚Äôs UI annotations and can‚Äôt be changed by users or SSCUIs.

Options,

  • Adapt UI: If enabled, check if you can adjust the field to show code & text (limited cases).
  • Custom app: Use CDS &  UI5 if this display is business critical.
  • Enhancement request: Submit via SAP Influence Portal.

SAP Help ‚Äì UI Text Arrangement

UI Text Guidelines for SAP Fiori Apps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Best Practice for data transfer between EPLAN and SAP...
entry.content:
Hello @JuliaLu 

The SAP ECTR Interface to EPLAN is only available for S/4HANA Private Cloud or On-Premise, not for S/4HANA Public Cloud (3SL).

Options for Public Cloud:

  • Use SAP Integration Suite (Standard Edition) to connect EPLAN via APIs or file exchange.
  • Leverage released APIs in S/4HANA Cloud (e.g. for materials, BOMs).
  • Set up a middleware or BTP staging layer to transform and push EPLAN data into SAP.

SAP Documentation References

  • SAP Note 3062953 ‚Äì ECTR and S/4HANA Cloud Compatibility
  • SAP API Hub ‚Äì Public APIs for S/4HANA Cloud

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Automatic Profitability Segment Derivation in "Post G...
entry.content:
Hello @Egorov_Evgeny 

The Post General Journal Entries app (F0718) does not support automatic CO-PA derivation of profitability segments in S4HANA Public cloud. Users must manually;

  1. Click Assign Profitability Segment
  2. Then hit Derive after entering the required fields

Even with substitution rules (SSCUI 102639/102640), the system won‚Äôt auto-trigger derivation during entry or save.

Possible Workarounds,

  • Use API_JOURNALENTRY_SRV to derive and pass the segment programmatically
  • Submit an influence request for native automation in the app

SAP KBA 3292146 ‚Äì Profitability segment assignment in Post General Journal Entries

Post General Journal Entries-Fiori App

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: "Keeping Up with the Compliance": AI-assisted Permit Management
entry.content:
There comes a moment in every environmental manager's day when the real enemy isn't the carbon footprint or the waste. It's the permits.

It lands in your inbox with a thud:

  • 791 pages,
  • titled something like Air Emissions Permit No. 3784/2025,
  • packed with phrases like "mandatory periodic verification of multi-stack filtration under transitional ozone-depleting discharge thresholds".

Naturally, you read it like it‚Äôs your side hustle‚Äôs side hustle.

"This'll take forever", you sigh, already mentally canceling lunch and spiritually detaching from joy.

But then it turns out, something familiar just got better.
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 just dropped. What are the odds? (No really, does anyone track these odds?)

You open the My Permits app. You're ready to grab that permit by the PDF and show it who's boss. Spoiler: it's not you.

"Wait, what's this?" you squint, half because it's 4:43 p.m. and half because you haven't blinked since 2019.
There it is, AI sparkles and all, shimmering like a rare loot drop in a dungeon crawler:

You click it faster than a good show gets canceled these days.
You upload your PDF file, you know the drill. And if you don't, this blog post's got you.

Only this time, you don't have to copy-paste anything to create your permit. ‚ú®AI does it for you.‚ú®
You hit Save and you get the same document displayed again, now side-by-side in the brand-new Compliance Requirement Document app. (Just in case you thought you'd seen the last of it.)

The document's on one side. You're on the other. You select a paragraph, and AI gets to work:

  • Suggested tasks pop up with titles, types, due dates, and proposed recurrence.
  • You can approve and tweak, or yeet them into oblivion.

Paragraphs instantly light up in color:

  • Blue means it's linked to a task,
  • Orange is due and overdue,
  • Green is done,
  • Red means something went wrong,
  • and gray is canceled (like your lunch break if this update hadn't dropped.)

...and before you know it, your 791-page regulatory horror novel gets digested by AI like it's legally obligated to care more than you do.

You lean back in your chair, sip your room-temp coffee like it's an Aperol Spritz, and exhale the sigh of someone who's just discovered what productivity used to feel like.

Is this real life? Is this just fantasy?
No, it's AI, baby. And it's live in My Permits (F5192).

üö®Cautionary Footnote Timeüö®
Your AI assistant is fast, helpful, and only mildly likely to become self-aware.
That said, it once tagged a glitter pen as Category 3 flammable. Review all AI-generated content before submission. Your future self will thank you. And so will your regulatory authority.

entry.title: Re: process to update same ZUONR/Assignment in both lines...
entry.content:
Hi @S0027096260 ,

Do it via user exit. -In EXIT_RFEBBU10_001, you will receive tables like I_FEBEP (bank statement line items) and E_FEBEP (export parameter, which you can modify).
-You need to identify the relevant information from the bank statement (e.g., from I_FEBEP-VWEZW which holds the note to payee, or other fields populated from Tag 61/86).
-Determine the value you want to use as the common ZUONR.
-Update the ZUONR field for both the bank account line and the offsetting account line within the E_FEBEP structure or the internal tables that hold the posting data.
-Set the export parameter E_UPDATE = 'X' to confirm that changes have been made.

This solution will work.
If you find my response helpful, kindly award a Kudos as small gesture which motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: What is SAP's official stance on using Business Area...
entry.content:
Hi @rajatp ,

1.Yes, SAP still supports Business Area in S/4HANA on-premise and private cloud, mainly for customers who were already using it before. It‚Äôs there to make the move to S/4HANA smoother without having to completely redo financial reporting setups. That said, SAP isn‚Äôt really developing it further, and their long-term focus is on using other dimensions for financial reporting.

2. SAP recommends using Profit Centers for internal and Segments for external reporting, including geographic breakdowns. If standard dimensions don‚Äôt cover your needs, custom fields in the Universal Journal offer flexibility. Functional Locations and Cost Centers can also reflect geography, though they serve more specific operational or cost-tracking purposes.

I hope this answer your question.
If you find my response helpful, kindly award a Kudos as small gesture which motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

No, the Professional Service Order app (J11) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, does not directly support configuring a service order type to behave like a sales order Bill of Material (BOM), allowing raw materials to be issued directly under a virtual material number within the service order structure.

entry.title: Re: Question about Logic creating PR type VFSB
entry.content:
In standard, VFSB PRs would appear in Closed Projects due to the following:-

MRP is still active on WBS elements or Networks, in which case, even if project is technically closed, the MRP may still treat them as open

  • if the final confirmation is not done
  • residual planned costs or materials are still present
  • Networks or activities have not been properly locked

If the material requirement is not deleted or marked as obsolete, MRP may continue to generate PRs

In order to overcome from the above issue,

  • suppress procurement via Control Keys
  • Set the Procurement Type to manual

You can also consider implementing BAdI MD_PURREQ_POST or BADI_MRP_REQ_RES to control PR creation during MRP runs. The logic can be in such a way to check if the linked Project / WBS / Network is marked as complete or locked

entry.title: Re: Flexible Stock Selection for Delivery ‚Äì Q Stock or Un...
entry.content:
As you would know Strategy Group E2 drives the requirement to link the material with some WBS element. Once that is set, MRP and ATP expect all movement types from project stock only and that is why, sales orders automatically demand Q-stock and bypass the unrestricted stock.

Try with the below approach

For stock determination, go to OMSL and OBBC to define how stock is selected during delivery processing. Set the configuration to prefer unrestricted stock first which you can make it based on storage location or sales order type. In material master MRP-2 view, you can see this Stock Determination Group. Stock determination rule can be per sales area and business scenario and finally, set the sequence to Unrestricted > Project > Blocked

entry.title: Re: Difference in VA05 output and BAPI_SALESORDER_GETLIST...
entry.content:
The reason for mismatch between va05 and BAPI could be due to the following:

  1. VA05 uses SD document status and user defined selection variants while BAPI may filter header status only unless configured
  2. VA05 includes all order types but BAPI might exclude customized order types unless explicitly requested
  3. VA05 includes partially confirmed schedules but BAPI might filter out completed schedules
  4. Finally, VA05 Open Order depends on standard SAP logic or based on user variant but BAPI needs explicit status flags (for example not delivered or not billed) in parameters

entry.title: Re: how the guaranteed value is calculating in the lc tra...
entry.content:
In vx11n, whatever total value is set would be the LC amount. Once a sales order is created and linked to LC, system considers the net value from VBAP. Tax, Freight and other charges would be considered depending upon your configuration
If the sales order currency is not equal to Local currency, then the value is recalculated using the exchange rate from TCURR table. SAP converts the order value to LC before comparison

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction

This is the first part of a multi-part series designed to walk you through the end-to-end setup and usage of Joule Studio. In this part, we'll focus on provisioning‚Äîlaying the foundation for a successful Joule Skill development journey.

Whether you're an architect, developer, or business process expert, this guide will help you correctly configure your SAP BTP environment, set up entitlements, and prepare your subaccount for secure and scalable development with Joule.

What is Joule Studio?

Joule Studio enhances the productivity and business impact of Joule, SAP's AI copilot. It is equipped with powerful capabilities designed to extend Joule‚Äôs intelligence to align with your organization‚Äôs specific processes, terminology, and needs.

Key Features:

  • Develop new Joule Skills for executing tailored, deterministic tasks aligned with business operations.
  • Manage and deploy updated skill versions to ensure continuous adaptability and improvement.
  • Define user access and permissions, ensuring the right teams can execute or administer the skills securely.
  • Seamlessly integrated with SAP Build, Joule Studio benefits from SAP's low-code/pro-code environment powered by generative AI.

SAP Joule Studio Architecture

 

Business Challenges and SAP's Solution

Business Challenges

  • Fragmented user experiences across enterprise applications.
  • Time-consuming manual processes, such as fetching business data.
  • Limited customization in out-of-the-box AI tools.
  • Technical complexity in onboarding automation tools.

SAP's Solution: Joule Studio with SAP Build

SAP addresses these challenges through:

  • Low-code development with SAP Build for quick customization.
  • Joule Booster to simplify provisioning and trust setup.
  • Joule Skills to extend the AI assistant with custom logic and backend integration.
  • BTP & IAS integration for secure, scalable access control.

 

Quotas

When using Joule Studio the following quotas apply.

A quota represents the numeric quantity that defines the maximum allowed consumption of a resource. In other words, how much of a service plan you're entitled to use.

You can find the quotas listed for Joule Studio below.

 

Action tasks

Connection timeout

1 minute

Time to establish the connection with the remote host.

 

Socket timeout

3 minutes

Maximum period between two data packets.

 

Total execution time

4 minutes

Total time an action task can execute.

 

Request body size

512 KB

 

 

Response content size

100 KB

 

Known Limitations

When using Joule Studio, note the following limitations:

  • The authorizations defined at environment level support users or user groups. Projects can be shared with a maximum of 10 user groups with execution or admin rights, or 5 users, and cannot be shared with a combination of user groups and users.
  • Deploying Joule skills to a shared environment in a production tenant can take up to 30 minutes.
  • It is possible to release and deploy a project in which no triggerable skills have been defined. However, this can lead to errors during the deployment.
  • When you use processes and automations from SAP Build Process Automation it is only possible for Joule Skills to start the processes or automations. Results from process and automations can not be integrated into the Joule skill flow.
  • If you type in values for Inputs or Outputs for your Joule skill and delete these manually, the value is missing but you can still release your project. The missing parameter can lead to errors when you run your Joule skill.
  • If you enter just a space, for example " ", in an input or output parameter, you can release your project but this can lead to errors during deployment.
  • When using a data type as input, if you use object binding to map to different fields, such as input and output parameters from other steps, this could lead to errors when you launch your Joule skill in Joule.
  • If you change permissions in a shared environment, you need to undeploy and redeploy the projects that have been deployed to the environment

Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure the following:

  • The SAP Build - build-default plan is available in your Global Account.

 

  • The Joule entitlement is assigned in your Global Account.

 

  • Your IAS tenant is automatically discovered in the System Landscape of your BTP Global Account.

Joule Studio supports the following data centers*:

Region Name

Region

Infrastructure Provider

Application Identifier

Subprocessor Region

Australia (Sydney)

AP10

Amazon Web Services (AWS)

das-application!b36397

Australia

Europe (Frankfurt)

EU10

das-application!b188376

Europe

sb-das-application!b7641

Europe

Europe

sb-das-application!b19666

US

* Subject to the availability of Joule Base and SAP Build.

 

Provisioning Setup

  • Create a Subaccount in a supported region and subscribe to SAP Build.

 

  • In the subaccount‚Äôs Trust Configuration, connect your IAS tenant via OpenID Connect (Joule does not support SAML).

 

  • Disable the Default Identity Provider for login.

 

  • Launch the Joule Booster from the Global Account:

 

 

    • Select your subaccount.

 

 

    • Choose SAP Build Process Automation under capabilities.

 

    • Add the SAP Build system using the build-default plan.

 

    • Complete the wizard by clicking Finish.

 

  • Once complete, navigate to System Landscape ‚Üí Formation.

 

  • In your subaccount:
    • Create the Joule Admin Role Collection, add all Joule roles, and assign your IAS user.

 

 

 

    • Create the ProcessAutomationAdmin Role Collection similarly.

 

 

In Part 2 of this series, we will dive into developing a custom Joule Skill‚Äîadding actions, inputs, and defining the skill logic using SAP Build.

Conclusion

With Joule Studio, businesses can extend SAP Joule's AI capabilities to address their unique operational needs‚Äîquickly and efficiently. From provisioning and configuration to skill development and testing, SAP provides a comprehensive framework that‚Äôs both powerful and secure.

By building custom Joule Skills within SAP Build, enterprises unlock new opportunities for automation, accelerate digital transformation, and empower users to achieve more with less complexity. Joule is not just an AI assistant‚Äîit‚Äôs your intelligent productivity partner.

entry.title: Re: CONSOLIDATION OF ENTITIES WITH DIFFERENT FISCAL YEAR...
entry.content:
Firstly, it is important to understand that with GRPL the source ledger in accounting becomes a part of GR. E.g. features such as the group view on accounting and validations on unreleased data require a consistent period definition (fiscal year variant). This is, in the source ledger of GR only, i.e. other ledgers such as the local GAAP and tax ledgers can have FYV as needed.

If for some reason the FYV cannot be harmonized, a different way of data integration can be chosen such as GRDC mapping which comes with powerful harmonization/transformation capabilities.

entry.title: Re: Crossboarding
entry.content:
@quirke31 

My suggestion is that the BPE errors could relate to various issues so its best to treat the error fixes independently and gradually watch the errors disappear with each onboarding restart from the BPE tool itself. 

You can create the fields in the requisition or application templates but DO NOT PERMISSION it to any of the operators. The only session that would reference the fields are the J permissions. And in recruit to hire data mapping, map them to the candidate template.

Note that if you do want the correct data to be passed, then its best to define and map them accurately - If the fields have been defined as mandatory, then they must be passed from the recruiting templates that you have mapped them to in recruit to hire data mapping. Otherwise, create dummy fields in the recruiting templates and map the EC fields to the dummy recruiting fields and validate.

A couple of links that are helpful include:

3012106 - [Onboarding] Passing Pay Component values through Picklist from RCM to ONB (Onboarding/Offboarding) - SAP for Me

Mapping Data from Recruiting Management with Employee Central Entities | SAP Help Portal

Elevating Internal Transfers Transitions through S... - SAP Community

https://me.sap.com/notes/3196075

https://me.sap.com/notes/3189216

https://me.sap.com/notes/3194225

Hopefully, your issues are resolved soon.

 

Regards,

Rac
